option_2_explanation.description: Feedback for option B explaining why it is correct or incorrect

differentiation_notes.description: How this question differs from the reference: text location, question type, aspect of standard assessed

quality_verification.description: Self-check of quality and diversity requirements

homogeneity_check.description: Confirmation that all choices belong to the same conceptual category

specificity_check.description: Confirmation that all choices have similar detail levels

length_check.description: Word counts for each choice confirming balance within 10%

semantic_distance_check.description: Confirmation that no distractors are synonyms or too close to correct answer

single_correct_check.description: Confirmation that only one answer is defensible as correct

diversity_check.description: Confirmation that this question targets different text, uses different question stem, and requires different reasoning than reference and other variants

prompt:
You are generating sibling questions for a grade 3 reading assessment.

## Article: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I

## Passage(s):
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
    
    
        There once was a poor boy named Aladdin. His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people. When his father died, Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.One day, a stranger walked up to Aladdin on the street. "Tell me, young man," said the stranger. "Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?""Yes, I am," said Aladdin.The stranger threw his arms around Aladdin and hugged him tight. "My dear nephew!" he cried out. "Your father was my brother! Now I learn that he has died! What terrible news!"

---

Aladdin brought the man home to meet his mother. She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother. Even so, she welcomed the man into their home. When the stranger promised to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money, she believed his words.But the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician who had traveled from far away in North Africa. He had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp. People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich. To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.

---

The next morning, the magician came to Aladdin's house. "Come with me today," he said to the boy. "I want to introduce you to other merchants in the city." Then he led Aladdin away from town and out into the countryside.The magician took Aladdin up a very steep mountain path. They climbed higher and higher for a whole hour. Finally, they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare."Go gather some dry sticks," the magician told Aladdin. "We will build a fire here. Then I will show you something truly amazing."Aladdin did exactly what the man asked him to do. The magician lit the fire with the sticks. Then he threw sweet-smelling perfumes into the flames and spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly, the bright sky turned dark like night. Thunder crashed and rumbled all around them. The earth split open right at their feet. There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring attached to it.

---

"Under this heavy stone lies a great treasure," said the magician. "It will make you richer than any king in the world. Lift the stone by pulling on the ring. Then go down the stairs. You will see many treasures as you walk, but you must not touch any of them. You will come to a beautiful garden. In that garden, you will see a lamp hanging from a tree. Bring that lamp back to me. Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want."Aladdin felt amazed by what he heard. He could hardly believe what the magician was asking him to do. But he agreed to help."Take this special ring," said the magician. "It will keep you safe from any harm." Aladdin took the ring and put it on his finger. Then he pulled the heavy stone up by its brass ring and went down into the dark cave below.Aladdin found the lamp and filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy. When he climbed back to the top of the stairs, he could not pull himself out of the cave opening."Give me your hand, Uncle," Aladdin called out. "Help me climb out!""First, hand me the lamp," the magician answered back.The lamp was buried deep in Aladdin's heavy bag. "I cannot reach it right now," Aladdin said.The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp. When Aladdin said he would give it to him after climbing out, the impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.

### Original Question (DOK 2, medium):
- Standard: RL.3.4 - Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
- Grade Level: grade 3
- Question: In the story, the magician tells Aladdin that finding the lamp will make him "richer than any king in the world."What does this phrase mean?
- A) Aladdin will have more money than he can count
- B) Aladdin will become the ruler of a kingdom
- C) Aladdin will find gold coins in the cave
- D) Aladdin will meet kings from other countries
- Correct Answer: A

- A) You successfully made a good prediction by using clues about the magic lamp and treasure. - B) You may have thought “richer than any king” means Aladdin becomes a king, or you used what you know from other versions, but the text says the lamp “would make any person very rich” and “It will make you richer than any king,” which is about money, not ruling. So the correct answer is that Aladdin w...
- C) You may have brought in outside ideas (gold coins), but the text never mentions coins—Aladdin finds “beautiful gems,” and the lamp is said to make a person “very rich,” even “richer than any king.” That means the best prediction is about how much wealth he will have, not a specific kind of money, so...

## Task:
Generate 4 NEW sibling question(s) for EACH original question above.
- Total questions to generate: 16
- Each sibling must have the SAME DOK, difficulty, and CCSS as its original
- Each sibling must test the SAME passage/section as its original
- Questions must be DIFFERENT from the originals (different focus, angle, or details)

## Quality Requirements (CRITICAL - All Must Be Met):

### Question Quality:
1. **Text Dependency**: Must require reading the passage to answer - cannot be answered with general knowledge
2. **Clear and Precise**: Unambiguous question with one correct answer
3. **Grade Appropriate**: Vocabulary and concepts suitable for the grade level
4. **Standard Alignment**: Question must directly assess the specific skill in the CCSS
5. **Template Fidelity**: Follow the original's question structure and cognitive demand

### Answer Choice Quality:
6. **Plausible Distractors**: Wrong answers should be believable but clearly incorrect
7. **Grammatical Parallelism**: All choices MUST follow the same grammatical structure
8. **Homogeneity**: All choices MUST belong to the same conceptual category
   - Do NOT mix character traits with setting details, or themes with specific facts
9. **Specificity Balance**: All choices MUST have similar levels of detail
   - GOOD: "happy", "sad", "angry", "worried" (all single emotion words)
   - BAD: "sad" vs "experiencing deep melancholy" (different detail levels)
10. **Length Balance**: Correct answer must NOT be the longest option
11. **Semantic Distance**: Distractors must NOT be synonyms of the correct answer

### Feedback/Explanations (REQUIRED for each choice):
For CORRECT answers: Why correct with text evidence + reading strategy
For INCORRECT answers: Common misconception + why wrong + correct answer + strategy tip

## Output Format:
Generate exactly 16 questions in the variant_questions array.

```json
{
  "variant_questions": [
    {
      "question": "The full question text here",
      "option_1": "First answer choice (A)",
      "option_2": "Second answer choice (B)",
      "option_3": "Third answer choice (C)",
      "option_4": "Fourth answer choice (D)",
      "correct_answer": "A",
      "option_1_explanation": "Detailed feedback for option A",
      "option_2_explanation": "Detailed feedback for option B",
      "option_3_explanation": "Detailed feedback for option C",
      "option_4_explanation": "Detailed feedback for option D",
      "differentiation_notes": "How this differs from reference: [text location], [question type], [aspect tested]",
      "quality_verification": {
        "homogeneity_check": "all choices are [category]",
        "specificity_check": "all choices are at [detail level]",
        "length_check": "balanced within 10%",
        "diversity_check": "targets different text than reference and other variants"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

Generate siblings in order: first all siblings for Question 1, then all siblings for Question 2, etc.
